points.title: Scripture & Gospel Centrality
points.description: Scripture as Authority and Centrality of the Gospel

subQuestions.text: Is Scripture viewed as the inerrant Word of God and used as the absolute standard for faith and practice?

options.label: Cultural Pressures Dominate
options.description: Scripture is often ignored or reinterpreted to fit cultural preferences. The Bible is not treated as authoritative.

options.label: Scripture Secondary
options.description: Scripture is respected but not consistently applied as the final authority. Cultural norms often override biblical teaching.

options.label: Mixed Practice
options.description: Scripture is generally viewed as authoritative, but application is inconsistent. Some areas follow biblical standards while others do not.

options.label: Scripture Primary
options.description: Scripture is consistently treated as the authoritative standard. Most decisions and practices align with biblical teaching.

options.label: Scripture Absolute
options.description: Scripture is the inerrant Word of God and the absolute standard for all faith and practice. It shapes every aspect of church life.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Take a moment to reflect: How does your church's view of Scripture compare to the description you selected? What evidence do you see in your community's practices and decisions?

subQuestions.text: Is there a general understanding that the Gospel is the grand and central theme of the Bible?

options.label: Gospel Absent
options.description: The Gospel is rarely mentioned or understood. Teaching focuses on other themes without connecting to the Gospel.

options.label: Gospel Peripheral
options.description: The Gospel is mentioned occasionally but is not seen as central. It's treated as one theme among many.

options.label: Gospel Recognized
options.description: The Gospel is understood as important, but its centrality to all of Scripture is not consistently emphasized.

options.label: Gospel Central
options.description: The Gospel is consistently taught as the central theme of Scripture. Most teaching connects back to the Gospel.

options.label: Gospel Everything
options.description: The Gospel is the grand and central theme that shapes all teaching, preaching, and understanding of Scripture. Everything points to Christ.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: When members read the Bible, do they see how every story, law, and prophecy points to Jesus? How is this understanding demonstrated in your church's teaching?

subQuestions.text: Are there clear pathways and practices that facilitate ongoing Gospel renewal?

options.label: No Pathways
options.description: There are no intentional practices or pathways for Gospel renewal. The church operates without regular spiritual refreshment.

options.label: Informal Practices
options.description: Some informal practices exist, but they are not clearly defined or consistently practiced across the church.

options.label: Some Pathways
options.description: There are some pathways for renewal, but they are not comprehensive or well-communicated to all members.

options.label: Clear Pathways
options.description: Clear pathways and practices exist for Gospel renewal. Most members know how to engage in ongoing spiritual refreshment.

options.label: Comprehensive Renewal
options.description: Multiple clear pathways and practices facilitate ongoing Gospel renewal. The entire church is equipped and engaged in regular spiritual refreshment.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: What specific practices help your church experience ongoing Gospel renewal? How accessible are these to every member?

subQuestions.text: Is there consistent weekly corporate worship that invites members to glorify God and make the Gospel clear and near?

options.label: Worship Inconsistent
options.description: Corporate worship is irregular or absent. When it happens, it does not clearly glorify God or present the Gospel.

options.label: Worship Occasional
options.description: Worship happens sometimes but is not consistent. The Gospel is mentioned but not made clear and near.

options.label: Regular Worship
options.description: Weekly worship is regular, but the Gospel is not consistently clear. Some services glorify God more than others.

options.label: Gospel-Centered Worship
options.description: Consistent weekly worship clearly glorifies God and makes the Gospel clear and accessible to all.

options.label: Transformative Worship
options.description: Every weekly service is designed to glorify God and make the Gospel clear and near. Worship transforms hearts and minds.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How does your weekly worship service make the Gospel clear and near? What elements specifically point people to Christ?

subQuestions.text: Are sound, expository, Gospel-centered and contextual sermons preached weekly?

options.label: No Sound Preaching
options.description: Sermons are not sound, expository, or Gospel-centered. They may be topical without biblical grounding or context.

options.label: Inconsistent Preaching
options.description: Some sermons are sound and Gospel-centered, but many are not. Expository preaching is rare.

options.label: Mixed Preaching
options.description: Preaching is generally sound but not consistently expository or Gospel-centered. Context is sometimes considered.

options.label: Solid Preaching
options.description: Weekly sermons are sound, expository, and Gospel-centered. They are contextual and relevant to the congregation.

options.label: Excellent Preaching
options.description: Every sermon is sound, expository, Gospel-centered, and deeply contextual. The Word is faithfully proclaimed and applied.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How would you describe the preaching in your church? Does it faithfully exposit Scripture and center on the Gospel?

subQuestions.text: Are the sacraments/ordinances of baptism and the Lord's Supper practised regularly and meaningfully?

options.label: Sacraments Neglected
options.description: Baptism and the Lord's Supper are rarely practiced or are treated as mere traditions without meaning.

options.label: Irregular Practice
options.description: Sacraments are practiced occasionally but not regularly. Their meaning is not clearly communicated.

options.label: Regular but Shallow
options.description: Sacraments are practiced regularly, but their Gospel significance is not consistently emphasized or understood.

options.label: Meaningful Practice
options.description: Baptism and the Lord's Supper are practiced regularly with clear Gospel meaning. Members understand their significance.

options.label: Rich Sacramental Life
options.description: Sacraments are practiced regularly and meaningfully. They are central to worship and clearly point to the Gospel.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How do baptism and the Lord's Supper function in your church? Do they clearly point to the Gospel and Christ's work?

subQuestions.text: Do elders and leaders enjoy and model a vibrant, Gospel-centered prayer life?

options.label: No Prayer Model
options.description: Leaders do not model prayer. Prayer is absent from leadership meetings and personal example.

options.label: Minimal Prayer
options.description: Leaders pray occasionally but do not model a vibrant prayer life. Prayer is not central to leadership.

options.label: Some Prayer
options.description: Leaders pray regularly, but it's not consistently vibrant or Gospel-centered. The model is inconsistent.

options.label: Good Prayer Model
options.description: Leaders model a vibrant, Gospel-centered prayer life. Prayer is central to leadership and visible to the church.

options.label: Excellent Prayer Model
options.description: Leaders consistently model a vibrant, Gospel-centered prayer life. Their example inspires and equips the church.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: What does the prayer life of your leaders communicate to the church? How is prayer modeled in leadership?

subQuestions.text: Is prayer a regular and joyful part of everyday church life?

options.label: Prayer Absent
options.description: Prayer is rarely part of church life. It's seen as a duty rather than a joy.

options.label: Prayer Occasional
options.description: Prayer happens sometimes but is not a regular part of church life. It's not consistently joyful.

options.label: Prayer Present
options.description: Prayer is a regular part of church life, but it's not always joyful. It may feel routine or obligatory.

options.label: Prayer Valued
options.description: Prayer is a regular and generally joyful part of church life. Members engage in prayer together regularly.

options.label: Prayer Central
options.description: Prayer is a regular, joyful, and central part of everyday church life. The church is marked by a culture of prayer.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How would you describe the prayer culture in your church? Is prayer seen as a joy or a burden?

subQuestions.text: Are members being invited and equipped for a true and rich prayer life?

options.label: No Equipping
options.description: Members are not invited or equipped for prayer. Prayer is not taught or modeled.

options.label: Minimal Equipping
options.description: Some members are invited to pray, but equipping is minimal. Prayer is not systematically taught.

options.label: Some Equipping
options.description: Members are invited to pray and receive some equipping, but it's not comprehensive or consistent.

options.label: Good Equipping
options.description: Members are regularly invited and equipped for a rich prayer life. Prayer is taught and practiced together.

options.label: Comprehensive Equipping
options.description: All members are consistently invited and equipped for a true and rich prayer life. Prayer is central to discipleship.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church equip members for prayer? What resources and practices help people grow in prayer?

subQuestions.text: Is the Gospel understood as the primary motivation for sanctification?

options.label: Gospel Not Motivation
options.description: The Gospel is not seen as motivation for growth. Sanctification is driven by rules, guilt, or performance.

options.label: Mixed Motivation
options.description: The Gospel is sometimes mentioned, but sanctification is primarily motivated by other factors like duty or fear.

options.label: Gospel Recognized
options.description: The Gospel is understood as important for motivation, but it's not consistently the primary driver of sanctification.

options.label: Gospel Primary
options.description: The Gospel is consistently taught as the primary motivation for sanctification. Growth flows from grace.

options.label: Gospel Everything
options.description: The Gospel is the clear and primary motivation for all sanctification. Everything flows from grace and gratitude.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: What motivates people in your church to grow? Is it the Gospel or something else?

subQuestions.text: Is 'all of life' discipleship taught and practiced as part of church life?

options.label: No All-of-Life Discipleship
options.description: Discipleship is limited to church activities. There's no teaching about following Jesus in all areas of life.

options.label: Limited Practice
options.description: All-of-life discipleship is mentioned but not consistently taught or practiced. It's mostly theoretical.

options.label: Some Practice
options.description: All-of-life discipleship is taught and practiced in some areas, but not comprehensively across the church.

options.label: Good Practice
options.description: All-of-life discipleship is consistently taught and practiced. Members are equipped to follow Jesus in all areas.

options.label: Comprehensive Practice
options.description: All-of-life discipleship is deeply embedded in church culture. Every area of life is seen as a place to follow Jesus.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church help people follow Jesus in their work, family, and daily life, not just at church?

subQuestions.text: Are there clear pathways for growth as disciples both for new believers and mature?

options.label: No Clear Pathways
options.description: There are no clear pathways for growth. New believers and mature Christians lack direction for discipleship.

options.label: Unclear Pathways
options.description: Some pathways exist but are not clear or well-communicated. People don't know how to grow.

options.label: Some Pathways
options.description: There are pathways for growth, but they may not be comprehensive or accessible to all members.

options.label: Clear Pathways
options.description: Clear pathways exist for growth at all stages. New believers and mature Christians know how to continue growing.

options.label: Excellent Pathways
options.description: Comprehensive, clear pathways for growth exist for all stages. The church is structured to help everyone grow as disciples.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: If someone new came to your church, would they know how to grow? What about someone who's been a Christian for 20 years?

points.title: NT Patterns of Church Life
points.description: New Testament Patterns of Church Life

subQuestions.text: Is every member encouraged and equipped for ministry?

options.label: Members Not Equipped
options.description: Members are not encouraged or equipped for ministry. Ministry is limited to a few leaders.

options.label: Limited Equipping
options.description: Some members are encouraged, but equipping is minimal. Most ministry is done by a small group.

options.label: Some Equipping
options.description: Members are encouraged and receive some equipping, but not all members are actively engaged in ministry.

options.label: Good Equipping
options.description: Most members are encouraged and equipped for ministry. There's a culture of every-member ministry.

options.label: Excellent Equipping
options.description: Every member is encouraged and equipped for ministry. The church operates with a strong every-member ministry model.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: What percentage of your members are actively engaged in ministry? How does your church equip people to serve?

subQuestions.text: Are small groups thriving, with leaders discipling members?

options.label: No Small Groups
options.description: There are no small groups, or they exist but are not functioning. Leaders are not discipling members.

options.label: Weak Groups
options.description: Small groups exist but are not thriving. Leaders may not be actively discipling members.

options.label: Some Thriving
options.description: Some small groups are thriving with leaders discipling members, but it's not consistent across all groups.

options.label: Mostly Thriving
options.description: Most small groups are thriving with leaders actively discipling members. There's a healthy small group culture.

options.label: All Thriving
options.description: Small groups are thriving across the church. Leaders are consistently discipling members in every group.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How would you describe the health of your small groups? Are leaders actively discipling members?

subQuestions.text: Is church discipline understood and practiced Biblically?

options.label: No Discipline
options.description: Church discipline is not understood or practiced. There's no process for addressing sin in the church.

options.label: Discipline Avoided
options.description: Church discipline is mentioned but rarely practiced. The church avoids addressing sin biblically.

options.label: Inconsistent Practice
options.description: Church discipline is understood but practiced inconsistently. Some situations are addressed, others are not.

options.label: Biblical Practice
options.description: Church discipline is understood and practiced biblically. The church addresses sin with grace and truth.

options.label: Excellent Practice
options.description: Church discipline is deeply understood and consistently practiced biblically. It's done with Gospel-centered grace and truth.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church handle sin and conflict? Is there a biblical process that's both gracious and truthful?

points.title: Leadership Development
points.description: Leadership Development and Biblically Qualified Elders (Self-Governing)

subQuestions.text: Does the church have a clear Leadership Development Pathway?

options.label: No Pathway
options.description: There is no clear pathway for leadership development. Leaders emerge without intentional equipping.

options.label: Unclear Pathway
options.description: Some leadership development exists but is not clear or systematic. The pathway is informal.

options.label: Some Pathway
options.description: There is a pathway for leadership development, but it may not be comprehensive or well-communicated.

options.label: Clear Pathway
options.description: A clear pathway exists for leadership development. Potential leaders know how to grow and be equipped.

options.label: Excellent Pathway
options.description: A comprehensive, clear pathway for leadership development exists. The church systematically develops leaders at all levels.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: If someone wanted to become a leader in your church, would they know the pathway? How clear is it?

subQuestions.text: Is there a clear pathway to identify and nurture Small Group Leaders?

options.label: No Small Group Pathway
options.description: There is no pathway to identify or nurture small group leaders. Leaders are chosen without clear process.

options.label: Informal Process
options.description: Small group leaders are identified informally, but there's no clear pathway for nurturing and equipping them.

options.label: Some Pathway
options.description: There is a pathway for small group leaders, but it may not be comprehensive or consistently applied.

options.label: Clear Pathway
options.description: A clear pathway exists to identify and nurture small group leaders. The process is well-defined and practiced.

options.label: Excellent Pathway
options.description: A comprehensive pathway identifies and nurtures small group leaders. They are well-equipped and supported.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church identify potential small group leaders? How are they nurtured and equipped?

subQuestions.text: Is there a pathway to identify, assess, train, and commission Deacons and Elders?

options.label: No Pathway
options.description: There is no pathway to identify, assess, train, or commission deacons and elders. The process is unclear or absent.

options.label: Informal Process
options.description: Deacons and elders are chosen informally without a clear pathway for assessment, training, or commissioning.

options.label: Partial Pathway
options.description: Some elements of the pathway exist, but it's not comprehensive. Assessment or training may be missing.

options.label: Clear Pathway
options.description: A clear pathway exists to identify, assess, train, and commission deacons and elders. The process is biblical and consistent.

options.label: Excellent Pathway
options.description: A comprehensive, biblical pathway exists for deacons and elders. They are carefully identified, assessed, trained, and commissioned.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How does your church identify and develop deacons and elders? Is the process biblical and clear?

subQuestions.text: Is there regular and healthy preaching on generosity?

options.label: No Preaching on Generosity
options.description: Generosity is rarely or never preached. When mentioned, it may be manipulative or guilt-driven.

options.label: Occasional Preaching
options.description: Generosity is preached occasionally, but not regularly. The teaching may not be consistently healthy or Gospel-centered.

options.label: Some Preaching
options.description: Generosity is preached regularly, but it may not always be healthy or consistently Gospel-centered.

options.label: Regular Healthy Preaching
options.description: Generosity is preached regularly and healthily. It's taught in a Gospel-centered way that's not manipulative.

options.label: Excellent Preaching
options.description: Generosity is regularly and excellently preached. It's consistently Gospel-centered, healthy, and transformative.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How is generosity taught in your church? Is it Gospel-centered and healthy, or does it feel manipulative?

subQuestions.text: Is there a culture of generosity and consistent giving?

options.label: No Culture of Generosity
options.description: There is no culture of generosity. Giving is minimal or inconsistent. Members are not generous.

options.label: Weak Culture
options.description: Some generosity exists, but it's not a strong culture. Giving is inconsistent across the church.

options.label: Growing Culture
options.description: A culture of generosity is developing. Many members give consistently, but it's not yet pervasive.

options.label: Strong Culture
options.description: There is a strong culture of generosity. Most members give consistently and generously.

options.label: Excellent Culture
options.description: An excellent culture of generosity permeates the church. Consistent, generous giving is the norm.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How would you describe the giving culture in your church? Is generosity a mark of your community?

subQuestions.text: Are all church operations funded through member giving (self-supporting)?

options.label: Not Self-Supporting
options.description: The church is not self-supporting. Operations depend heavily on external funding or are unsustainable.

options.label: Partially Supported
options.description: Some operations are funded by members, but the church relies significantly on external support.

options.label: Mostly Self-Supporting
options.description: Most operations are funded by members, but there may be some reliance on external support.

options.label: Self-Supporting
options.description: All church operations are funded through member giving. The church is self-supporting.

options.label: Fully Self-Supporting
options.description: All operations are fully funded through member giving. The church is not only self-supporting but also generous to others.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: Is your church self-supporting? How does member giving compare to your operational needs?

points.title: City Culture Engagement
points.description: City Culture and People are Being Engaged with the Gospel; People Being Saved

subQuestions.text: Is the church ministering to Christians and non-Christians simultaneously in worship?

options.label: Not Ministering to Both
options.description: Worship is designed for only one groupâ€”either Christians or non-Christians, but not both simultaneously.

options.label: Primarily One Group
options.description: Worship primarily serves one group. The other group is considered but not intentionally ministered to.

options.label: Some Balance
options.description: Worship attempts to minister to both groups, but the balance is inconsistent or not well-executed.

options.label: Good Balance
options.description: Worship effectively ministers to both Christians and non-Christians simultaneously. Both groups are intentionally served.

options.label: Excellent Balance
options.description: Worship excellently ministers to both groups simultaneously. The service is designed to serve believers and seekers together.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How does your worship service serve both believers and non-believers? Is it accessible to both?

subQuestions.text: Are vibrant Faith & Work practices integrated into discipleship?

options.label: No Faith & Work Integration
options.description: Faith and work are not integrated. Work is seen as separate from faith, and there's no teaching on this.

options.label: Minimal Integration
options.description: Faith and work are mentioned occasionally, but there's no vibrant integration into discipleship.

options.label: Some Integration
options.description: Faith and work are integrated in some ways, but it's not consistently vibrant or comprehensive.

options.label: Good Integration
options.description: Vibrant Faith & Work practices are integrated into discipleship. Members are equipped to serve God in their work.

options.label: Excellent Integration
options.description: Vibrant Faith & Work practices are deeply integrated into discipleship. Work is seen as a primary place of mission.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church help people see their work as mission? Is Faith & Work part of discipleship?

subQuestions.text: Is there intentional and compassionate practice of Mercy and Justice?

options.label: No Mercy & Justice
options.description: There is no intentional practice of mercy and justice. The church does not engage in compassionate action.

options.label: Occasional Practice
options.description: Mercy and justice are practiced occasionally, but not intentionally or consistently across the church.

options.label: Some Practice
options.description: There is some intentional practice of mercy and justice, but it may not be comprehensive or consistently compassionate.

options.label: Good Practice
options.description: Intentional and compassionate practice of mercy and justice is a regular part of church life.

options.label: Excellent Practice
options.description: Intentional and compassionate practice of mercy and justice is central to the church's mission and identity.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How does your church practice mercy and justice? Is it intentional, compassionate, and integrated into mission?

points.title: Evangelism Contextualization
points.description: Believers Able to Share the Gospel in Multiple Contextual Ways

subQuestions.text: Do believers understand the Gospel clearly and are they being equipped to share it?

options.label: No Understanding or Equipping
options.description: Believers do not clearly understand the Gospel and are not equipped to share it. Evangelism is rare.

options.label: Limited Understanding
options.description: Some believers understand the Gospel, but equipping to share it is minimal. Most are not equipped.

options.label: Some Equipping
options.description: Believers generally understand the Gospel and receive some equipping, but it's not comprehensive.

options.label: Good Equipping
options.description: Believers clearly understand the Gospel and are well-equipped to share it. Most members can articulate the Gospel.

options.label: Excellent Equipping
options.description: All believers clearly understand the Gospel and are excellently equipped to share it. Evangelism is natural and common.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: Can most members of your church clearly explain the Gospel? How are they equipped to share it?

subQuestions.text: Are members building friendships with non-Christians and engaging them in Gospel conversations?

options.label: No Friendships
options.description: Members are not building friendships with non-Christians. Gospel conversations are rare or absent.

options.label: Limited Friendships
options.description: Some members have friendships with non-Christians, but Gospel conversations are infrequent.

options.label: Some Engagement
options.description: Many members have friendships with non-Christians, and some Gospel conversations happen, but it's not widespread.

options.label: Good Engagement
options.description: Most members are building friendships with non-Christians and regularly engaging in Gospel conversations.

options.label: Excellent Engagement
options.description: Members consistently build friendships with non-Christians and regularly engage in natural Gospel conversations.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How many members of your church have meaningful friendships with non-Christians? Are Gospel conversations happening?

subQuestions.text: Do members understand and address cultural "defeater beliefs" winsomely?

options.label: No Understanding
options.description: Members do not understand defeater beliefs and cannot address them. Cultural objections are ignored or mishandled.

options.label: Limited Understanding
options.description: Some members understand defeater beliefs, but most cannot address them winsomely. Responses may be defensive.

options.label: Some Ability
options.description: Many members understand defeater beliefs and can address some of them, but not consistently winsomely.

options.label: Good Ability
options.description: Most members understand and can address cultural defeater beliefs winsomely. The church is equipped for this.

options.label: Excellent Ability
options.description: Members consistently understand and winsomely address cultural defeater beliefs. The church is well-equipped for cultural engagement.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: How does your church help people understand and respond to common objections to Christianity? Is it done winsomely?

subQuestions.text: Do leaders and members understand and appreciate the Biblical charge to plant churches?

options.label: No Understanding
options.description: Leaders and members do not understand or appreciate the biblical charge to plant churches. It's not on the radar.

options.label: Limited Understanding
options.description: Some leaders understand church planting, but it's not widely appreciated. The charge is not clearly communicated.

options.label: Some Understanding
options.description: Leaders and many members understand the charge to plant churches, but it's not deeply appreciated or prioritized.

options.label: Good Understanding
options.description: Leaders and most members understand and appreciate the biblical charge to plant churches. It's part of the vision.

options.label: Excellent Understanding
options.description: Leaders and members deeply understand and appreciate the biblical charge to plant churches. It's central to identity.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: How does your church view church planting? Is it seen as a biblical mandate or an optional activity?

subQuestions.text: Does the church have meaningful partnerships with other churches and para-church organizations?

options.label: No Partnerships
options.description: The church has no meaningful partnerships. It operates in isolation from other churches and organizations.

options.label: Limited Partnerships
options.description: Some partnerships exist but are not meaningful or strategic. The church is mostly isolated.

options.label: Some Partnerships
options.description: The church has some meaningful partnerships, but they may not be comprehensive or consistently engaged.

options.label: Good Partnerships
options.description: The church has meaningful partnerships with other churches and para-church organizations. Collaboration is regular.

options.label: Excellent Partnerships
options.description: The church has excellent, strategic partnerships. It works collaboratively with others for the sake of the Gospel.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Consider: What partnerships does your church have? Are they meaningful and strategic for the Gospel?

subQuestions.text: Does the leadership demonstrate a movement mindset and intentionally live it out?

options.label: No Movement Mindset
options.description: Leadership does not demonstrate a movement mindset. The church operates as an isolated institution.

options.label: Limited Mindset
options.description: Some leaders have a movement mindset, but it's not consistently demonstrated or intentionally lived out.

options.label: Some Demonstration
options.description: Leadership demonstrates a movement mindset in some ways, but it's not comprehensive or consistently intentional.

options.label: Good Demonstration
options.description: Leadership consistently demonstrates a movement mindset and intentionally lives it out. The church thinks beyond itself.

options.label: Excellent Demonstration
options.description: Leadership excellently demonstrates a movement mindset and intentionally lives it out. The church is part of a larger movement.

subQuestions.reflection_text: Reflect: Does your church think like a movement or an institution? How is this demonstrated in leadership decisions?
